explanation:
To determine whether OS_CloseAllFiles violates the MISRA C "for loop shall be well-formed" rule you must know whether any for-loops exist (or are affected) inside the code paths exercised by this function and whether loop counters or control flags are modified in loop bodies or via called functions. The following symbols are required and why:

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext: This function is used as the loop condition (while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))). Its implementation may contain for-loops or persistent side-effects; it may also modify iterator state that serves as an implicit loop counter/control. Knowing its body is necessary to see whether any for-loops it contains are well-formed and whether it modifies objects used as loop counters in surrounding loops.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry: Called inside the loop body. According to the static graph it may call other routines; its implementation might itself contain for-loops or modify objects that could act as loop counters. Also MISRA treats the behaviour of called functions as part of the loop body, so you must inspect this symbol for any for-statement violations or side effects on loop counters.

- OS_FileIteratorClose: This is the callback passed to OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry. Its code executes as part of the loop body and therefore must be inspected for any for-loops, modifications of loop counters, or side-effects that would make an outer for statement ill-formed.

- OS_ObjectIdIterateActive: Initializes iteration before the loop. It may call initialization helpers (e.g. iterator init) that influence iterator state or contain for-loops; you need its implementation to determine whether any for-loops there or effects on iterator/loop counters are relevant to overall compliance.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit: Callee of OS_ObjectIdIterateActive. The iterator init routine may set up internal counters or contain loops; inspect to ensure no ill-formed for-loops or modifications of objects used later as loop counters.

- OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy: Called after the loop; its implementation (and any internal loops) must be checked because MISRA's notion of loop behaviour includes called functions — destroy may also reveal how the iterator is used and whether objects used as loop counters are modified elsewhere.

- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Callee of OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy. Included because it may contain loops or modify iterator-related state or shared objects that could be used as loop counters in other code paths.

- OS_ObjectIdFromToken: Callee of OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry. It might access/modify object identifiers or iterator tokens; if it contains for-loops or alters objects used as loop counters, that affects MISRA compliance for any for-loops in the call chain.

- OS_Lock_Global / OS_Unlock_Global: Called by OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry. Lock/unlock functions are included because they may wrap blocks that include loops or otherwise affect concurrency/state that could alter loop control objects; MISRA requires considering behaviour of called functions within loops.

- OS_object_iter_t (type definition): The iterator type definition is needed to determine which fields constitute the loop counter/control state (e.g., an index or token). To decide if any for-loop uses/violates the rule you must know which iterator fields are modified and whether they are used as loop counters or modified in called functions.

Note: The static call graph also shows test/UT stub functions (UT_*) being reachable; include them only if the unit-under-test instrumentation is present in the build being analyzed. The symbols above are the minimal set needed to determine whether any for-loops involved in the iteration/control flow are well-formed and whether called functions modify loop counters or control flags in ways that would violate the MISRA rule.
